have more than you need or is it enough perhaps

there is a fine difference between the 
things you want and the things you need

to want is to desire it is an urge to satisfy 
that desire to need is the instinctive response

to nature's call for survival it's the need to 
survive what is necessary to survive is your

need the obvious things needed for survival 
are food and water they are your basic needs

without these you will not survive for long of 
course want can be classified as need to however

we often see want as a more selfish emotion i need 
food i want a nice new car to show my neighbour

furthermore the dilemma of what money is creates 
quite a paradox we need money to buy food but we

also want money to support a comfortable 
and some might say wasteful lifestyle

want is often seen as a selfish emotion 
need comes from your basic necessities

want comes from the things that will make you 
feel better as a person need comes from the

basic survival instinct to make it through 
the day without starving to death need and

want might have similar definitions but they are 
often seen as belonging to very different urges

what is a split infinitive is it painful will

infinitive is not an injury although it does sound 
like one in english grammar we name a certain

grammar error as a split infinitive an infinitive 
in english grammar is the use of the word to

with a verb while there are no grammar rules that 
prohibit split infinitives many english experts

strongly disapprove of them an example of a 
split infinitive is the classic to boldly go

where no man has gone before the word boldly and 
go should be the other way round it should read

to go boldly where no man has gone before in 
writing this looks more dramatic but when spoken

the split infinitive sounds better so 
while the use of a split infinitive

is technically incorrect you might only find the 
most pedantic english teachers picking you upon it

correct them by pointing out their mistake
